title: Compressing Product Innovation Timelines from Months to Days with AI | Amir Ouki, BOI

rawLines.text: Today on Just Curious, we're joined by
Amir Uki, a sharp commercially minded AI
strategist who helps some of the world's
biggest companies reimagine how they
innovate. As managing director of
applied AI at BOI, Amir leads teams
building AI native capabilities for
clients across consumer goods,
healthcare, financial services, and
more. He's worked with cutting edge
companies like Anthropic, Apple,
Palanteer, and Airbnb. And he's known
for making bold, complex systems
actually work at scale. In this
conversation, you'll learn how companies
are compressing product development from
months to days using agentic systems and
synthetic consumers. Why off-the-shelf
AI tools often fall short and how Amir
builds secure IPOed systems instead, and
how to avoid AI theater by anchoring
everything in commercial logic and
business outcomes. Amir, welcome to Just
Curious. Hey Stu, happy to be here.
You've worked at the intersection of
strategy, design, and technology. Can
you tell us a little bit more about your
journey and what drew you to focus on
AI? Yeah, for sure. So, I originally
started more on the strategy side of
things, more traditional strategy. So
working through business strategy,
commercial strategy and brand strategy
and eventually found myself at the
software intersection and working in
building software at a really great
studio called fictive kin and started to
really immerse in what strategic
technology is. So building systems that
are scalable, that are modular, but
ultimately that are really solving
business challenges, which lends itself
obviously very very clearly to AI, which
I consider to be a highly strategic
technology. It's a technology that we
can leverage, that we can design, that
we can manipulate into solving
challenges that were just really, really
hard before. So my journey has been
somewhat of a organic one through
strategy software and then eventually
merging the two into strategic
technology. Tell us a little bit more
about
BOI and what you do and who you did it
for. Yeah, so BOI we have two main areas
of focus which are AI strategy so
broadly helping companies identify when
where and and how to use AI in their
organizations and then the second focus
is technology. So thinking about how to
build real world AI solutions that are
solving real world challenges and a lot
of those different solutions those
different capabilities are usually in
the space of augmented decision-m
simulation genic workflows as you said
earlier and also starting to do a lot
more work now in the field of agentic
commerce. So BI, we are a global company
and I head up America's region over here
in our New York office and we also have
a a very big Europe market as well based
out of Belgium. We're going to walk
through how BOI helps clients develop
and innovation capabilities and turn
signals into products. But I'd love to
share a little bit more from your
learnings as as a setup and maybe we
could start with what to do with AI.
Okay. So, a lot of leaders are being
told do something with AI, but they
don't know where to start. When you're
working with a team, how do you help
them define a real business use case and
a place to start? Mhm. It's it's really
really important. So, whenever we are
really doing anything in AI, we always
start from the challenge first and not
AI. So, that ability that kind of
business strategy that I that I
mentioned earlier is really important.
You have to know what your challenges
are. You have to be able to articulate
them. You have to also be able to kind
of deconstruct them into sub challenges.
And then once you've got a really good
sense of what you are trying to solve
for, that's the right time to say, okay,
what kind of AI technologies will will
help us solve this. I think we see a lot
of people start with the latter and
they'll see AI around or see a specific
use case of AI or maybe a specific
vendor and then try and reverse engineer
that back into their system. But that's
that's really hard to do. It's always
easier and you're in a better position
as as a company to say what are our
challenges, what do we need to solve and
then say okay how do we need to go out
and solve them. So we focus primarily on
identification what are those challenges
and then evaluating them saying what
figuring out essentially what needs to
be solved how it needs to be solved how
we got there what the right AI
technologies could be and then we think
about prioritization right so of all
these different challenges that we have
and all the different use cases that
could emerge from them with AI how do we
prioritize these into impact how do we
think about feasibility how do we think
about what a scalable system starts to
look like and then let that guide what
an initial foray could be. You said in
our earlier conversation that growth is
back on everyone's mind, but headcount
isn't the preferred lever it once was.
What kind of problems does AI let
companies solve now that they couldn't
solve before? Yeah, I think what we see
is is to that point, it's it's an
interesting and and somewhat tricky
market that's we're in at the moment
when it comes to the economy and that's
very much on the mind of of every client
that we work with and it has been for a
little while. So, a lot of them are
approaching AI from the lens of we we
may not have the budget and the
resources to expand our headcount as
aggressively as we could previously. So
where is there a role for AI in still
allowing us to scale the really great
talent that we have but be able to think
about how how we can augment that. So I
think the example that um this this kind
of position you're referencing is is
what we call the previously impossible,
right? So what could we what can we do
with AI today that we previously
couldn't do? And I think there's there's
different ways to tackle that. One of
the big ones is just being able to do a
lot more with a huge amount of data is
is the first one that people usually
think of. It was very very difficult
before to let's say generate insights or
generate signals or assess previous data
and and figure out patterns from
previous data. It was very hard to do
that manually and it's it's still not
extremely easy but it's much easier than
it was before to be able to leverage the
data sets that you have whether
structured or unstructured that um that
just haven't been leveraged before. So
the the first thing that comes to mind
is just the scale of what you can do
with AI that you couldn't before by
being resource resource constrained. I
don't want
to provide examples that people try and
back solve from, but you've worked
closely with innovation and
transformation and supply chain leaders.
Where do you see the biggest
opportunities and appetite for AI today?
Yeah, I think that across any function
and we work with with different
functions and different groups. I think
the through line probably is the the
growth through line. Certainly in the in
the US markets, I think there's three
different outcomes usually that people
are are working towards with AI. And the
first one is new revenue. How can we use
it to generate new revenue, find new
segments, find new audiences, launch new
products? The second is revenue
optimization. So, how can we use AI to
get more out of the products that we
already have in market or the services
that we have in market? How do we think
about our consumers? How do we think
about clustering those consumers? How do
we think about marketing? And then the
third one, which is usually where
people's mind begins, is efficiency and
productivity, right? How do we use AI to
automate? How do we use AI to do what
we're already doing, but do it in a more
efficient way? And I think that even
though that third bucket is where people
start, usually it's the other two that
is driving meaningful investment in in
building with AI. It's saying, "Okay,
well, actually, if we invest $1 and we
can get $2 out of this new capability in
terms of new revenue, that's really,
really appealing across all functions."
And the same for revenue optimization as
well. If there's a way that we're able
to maximize the growth potential of our
existing portfolio of products, it's a
really good return compared to just
focusing on automation or efficiency or
or productivity. So while we do work
between those different functions that
you mentioned, I think that through line
is just a a drive at the moment for
growth and and just resiliency in in the
current market. And when it comes to
that growth, you mentioned revenue
optimization, you mentioned new
products, segmenting customers in
different ways, without going into too
much detail, where where are kind of the
easiest wins there when it comes to
applying AI to drive growth? And I asked
because one, as you noted, uh it can
create more value than just becoming
more efficient. Two, it just runs
counter to most of the conversations
around AI, which are let's um become
more efficient, which is code for doing
more with the same people or the same
with fewer. So yeah, curious for your
kind of like highle thoughts about when
it comes to revenue growth, where where
are kind of the uh most interesting
opportunities? Yeah, I mean, as always,
it depends on the company, the industry
that you're in. And I think just in
general with AI, the the phrase quick
win or easy win is always one I I try to
avoid cuz I think there's not too many
quick wins when it comes to enterprise
AI, our personal lives, and and AI in
the day-to-day that we use. I think
there's there's so many, but when we
think about enterprise AI, there's
usually a minimum threshold of of kind
of engagement needed to get some of that
return back. But I think where we tend
to see people starting are within the
existing portfolio of products and
services that they may have depending on
what kind of company you are. So
thinking about how do you win business
at the moment? How can you win more of
that business? What are the friction
points in your sales cycle and how can
you use AI to minimize some of those
friction points. So an example that I
would give is that we do quite a bit of
work in the industrials sector and
there's a really interesting specific
use case around quoting that we see with
a lot of manufacturing companies that we
work with where they just have really
slow quoting times or really slow
turnaround times when they're working
with different OEMs and different
clients. It's one that AI does lend
itself pretty well to. It's a it's a
common thread. It's not the mostated
problem to solve, but it does involve a
level of customization given that every
company's quoting process is different.
If I were to just call out an example of
something that comes to mind, that is a
a relatively, for one of a better
phrase, quick hit when it comes to
revenue driving. Something like that is
is I think a good example. Just
something as simple as quoting and
turnaround times and how different
companies are able to get proposals out
the door. We've heard of proposals from
manufacturing companies sometimes taking
6 weeks to to reach the client which by
that point obviously is somewhat
compromising the revenue potential.
Yeah. Interesting. Many teams start with
offtheshelf tools and certainly when it
comes to enterprise adoption whether
it's enterprise licenses of your kind of
model of choice that was the first step.
Why do they often fall short and how do
you help these teams build custom
solutions that actually scale? Yeah, the
buy versus build question is a really
it's a really tricky one. There is no
right or wrong is the first thing that
we always say. Build is not always
right. Buy is not always right. We
ourselves are not affiliated with any
vendors. So we we I think have a strong
neutral position and we're constantly
assessing different tools and different
vendors and different SAS solutions out
there. I think where where we've seen
SAS starts to break certainly at the
enterprise level is twofold. One is the
data the data question. We work with a
lot of companies that just are not in a
position to let their data leave their
own environment, let alone go off into a
SAS tool. This is the case with every
Fortune 500 company that we work with.
There's just no chance that they're
using a uh an external SAS tool and
putting their data into it. So what
they're ultimately able to do if they do
use a vendor is to just be able to use
it as an outsider. They're not able to
actually leverage that data. So they
don't get so much value out of it. So
one is the data security question and
the second is the customization. And
whenever we're building any kind of AI
capability, it really is designed with
that team in mind. So we're thinking
about what is the specific commercial
logic that is relevant to that team.
We're also thinking about how do they
work right now? What is their existing
process? What makes them really strong?
what are the blockers individually that
they have and how can we unblock those
those obstacles in whatever we're
building for them. So that level of I
guess customization is is probably the
word you just can't get with different
SAS tools. So those are the two big
blockers that I would say that prevent
at least the clients that we work with
from being able to meaningfully engage
with with but I think for smaller
companies there's there's a really
interesting opportunity there and it
just doesn't make sense for a lot of
them to be building that kind of
platform from the ground up. Yeah. Do
you think AI is different than prior
technology shifts with respect to its
enablement of a startup ecosystem? I
asked because there are thousands of AI
startups but to your point for many
companies a offthe-shelf startup
solution is not going to work whether
it's you know data or something else. Do
you think AI is just different and that
these startups are going to have a
harder time? You've heard about as an
example agentic startups transitioning
let's call it to more of a service
provider model. Um curious for your
thoughts on that. Yeah it's an
interesting one. So just kind of a a
caveat, we don't do too much work as boi
in the in the startup space itself, but
I'll say just kind of as an observer, I
think that it is going to be a tricky
market for a lot of the AI startups that
have emerged in the last year or two. I
do think that it'll end up likely being
a winner takes all situation as with
software all the time. So I think a lot
of the startups are going to struggle. I
think likely one of their biggest
competitors is it's not going to be each
other, it's going to be internal teams.
I think that where they will struggle is
just companies building some version of
these capabilities themselves. So as we
kind of democratize access to building
tools both for people that don't have
technical teams but companies that do
have technical teams already, it just is
a lot easier for them to stand up at
least an MDP version of what a lot of
the the SAS companies out there are
doing. That's certainly not all of them
and this is definitely just a hunch and
I think it's so important to have a
healthy ecosystem, but I I do think it's
it's going to be choppy waters
potentially. Let's talk about agents for
a minute. What do you mean when you talk
about agentic reasoning systems and how
do they fit into and help transform
enterprise workflows? Yeah, it's a
really good question. So, we think of
the um the whole agent sphere as being
much more of a spectrum. And there was
definitely a moment in time, I would say
around a year ago, maybe even 6 months
ago, where agents were very much on
everyone's mind. And I think that there
was almost kind of a land grab for who
could define what an agent was. And you
just heard all these different
definitions of of what an agent really
is. It needs to be autonomous. It needs
to be self-hosted. You know, it was kind
of a marketing frenzy around agents. But
the way that we think about it is less
the individual entity itself. So when I
think of when people tend to reference
an agent, they're usually thinking of
some kind of defined entity that is
acting in some kind of defined
environment and it could be something
like a chatbot for customer service or a
research assistant for example. But I
think for us when we're thinking about
the value of an agentic system, we think
a bit more from the reasoning
standpoint. So almost a spectrum of
autonomy where you can have agents that
are very much running on predefined
paths and you can have agents that are
running on paths that are less defined.
I don't think we're anywhere near the
point of autonomous agents at the moment
and I'm not sure what the future for
that would look like. But we think of
agentic reasoning as basically what is
that process? What's that capability by
which multiple agents or a system of
agents can make decisions, can
deconstruct problems, can evaluate
outcomes and coordinate actions. So that
for us is is the reasoning um the
reasoning process and then that gets
applied basically to any challenge that
we're trying to solve. We could be using
that kind of setup to figure out what a
new signal can be in this giant trove of
social listening data. It could be that
we are using this kind of agentic setup
for scenario modeling or to do more
complex simulation. So really it's it's
it's fairly agnostic in where it lives.
But that's how we think of it versus
just your your agent that you may see
from maybe a big tech company or or a
lot of the the marketing that you see
out there at the moment. Yeah. Um I want
to show viewers and listeners more of
how you work. We talked earlier about a
example of working with a CPG company to
help them build kind of endtoend
innovation capabilities going from
signal to product. Can you walk us
through that process? Um where where do
you start? Yeah. So I think that's a a
good uh a good use case example maybe to
show a our flow of what a typical
project works with although none of them
are are particularly typical but we have
worked with a lot of companies
especially in um in CPG
where the endto-end new product
development capability is a huge part of
the business and it's also a very
complex part of the business. So we've
been actually building AI capabilities
that will run that entire process really
end to end with the existing new product
development team and that could be an
innovation team, it could be an R&D
team. Often times it's it's sometimes
sales and marketing teams that are
running the go to markets portion of
this process. It's generally a
collaborative kind of inter team
capability but it can start with
innovation or transformation usually but
we are essentially using AI to start
with a signal and different sets of
signals. So we'll take internal data,
we'll take external data out there in
the world, we'll take third party data,
meaning data that one of these companies
is is already purchasing or has
purchased or has a license agreement
from one of their vendors. We take all
of that and then we'll use essentially
AI systems to generate opportunity
spaces from those. Well, generate
insights from those, then turn those
insights into opportunity spaces and
then start to really ideulate and
concept and think about what could new
products look like, what could new
services look like, what could new
business models look like, for example.
And then take those and then rigorously
test them again through simulation,
through really rigorous synthetic
testing. And we'll use that agentic
reasoning approach that I mentioned
earlier to figure out, okay, does this
meet desiraability requirements? Does
this meet feasibility requirements? Does
this meet viability requirements? And
doing that end to end, you can get from
a set of just raw data that's out there
in the world to a really refined final
concept. It could be for a new product.
It could be an adjustment on an existing
product. So, it doesn't necessarily have
to be just new product development or
innovation. It can be your existing
portfolio. But you can get from that
signal to launch really, really fast.
And it's just been very empowering, I
think, for a lot of the teams that we've
been working with to be able to take a
process that typically would have taken
them a lot of manual work over 6 8
months and be able to get to really
validated new product development much
much faster. And then what we see for
those roles is that they're actually
able to spend a lot more time now
prototyping it and making it real and
testing it with real people instead of
spending so much time on the funnel
process where a lot of the ideas
ultimately are and invested in ideas
that are not not ready to go to market.
It's been a a really fun it's been a
really fun capability. We've done it
quite a bit for companies actually in
many different sectors. for uh for
people who have not done that with you
before. You mentioned you're able to
compress the sort of the calendar from 6
to 8 months to something much shorter.
Understanding everything is different
for each individual situation and client
like approximately how much compression
can one expect from using a AI powered
process like this. Mhm. Depending on
what the process looks like, it's very
different for different folks. So we
design it, we build it in a different
way for each of the teams we work with.
We have some teams that really will lean
into functionality like forecasting or
opportunity sizing. We have other teams
that are more interested in
functionality like turning those
concepts into factory ready production
specs. So just for context, it can it
can live and express in different ways,
but I'd say end to end it comes down to
just a couple of days,
which is a pretty substantial change.
Yeah. You mentioned synthetic consumers
and customers. What does that mean? So
essentially what we're doing is we are
replicating the behaviors, the intrinsic
motivations especially of traditional
consumers. So we are trying to get them
as close as possible to a set of
sometimes personas, sometimes archetypes
that often times companies may have to
start with. They may have really
rigorous persona uh persona data. They
may have incomplete persona data which
we're enriching with AI. But essentially
what we're trying to do is we're
mirroring real human behaviors as
closely as we can. So it's the behaviors
and it's the intrinsic motivators as
well that are behind those behaviors.
What do you say to people who push back
and say, "But these aren't real." I
think that's very correct. It it
absolutely is not real. And one of the
first things that we always say is that
this the outcome of this is to get as
close as we can to winning ready
services and concepts, ideas that will
perform really well in marketing, get
you as close as possible. There's always
a human in the loop and there will
always be a human making the decisions
throughout this process and saying okay
this is what we want to explore further
this is what we might put into physical
prototyping and a lot of the time our
clients will say okay great we've got
three winning concepts here let's put
this in the hands of real consumers
which which is important we actually
have one client that hasn't done that
and quite literally ships these concepts
straight to factories and tests them in
market from the get- go it's going
straight to a factory It's then getting
deployed straight to three or four
stores. It's a retail client and they'll
get a sense in those stores of how the
product is performing with real actual
purchase data. Have people bought this
or not? If they have, then this is a
good signal for us to expand this to to
other stores. But that's that's an
exception. For everyone else, it does
end up in the hands of real consumers.
And for now, I would advise that that
that continues. So, the goal is not to
replace consumers entirely. the goal is
how can we get to you know winning. Uh
any other challenges whether technical
or cultural or strategic that you face
when deploying these kind of systems?
You know there are many many different
challenges that are um involved in just
AI in general. Uh the obvious one is
thinking about data scalability. Uh we
always always always approach building
anything from an MVP an MVP approach
your kind of traditional start small
focus on just proving out the key
hypothesis and a lot of our clients are
multibrand clients so they uh they'll
have a lot of household names we'll say
let's pick one and let's test out uh
let's test out this capability on just
this one brand or this one category
within the business but we always say
start with a PC prove out the value
first and then build it in a way that is
scalable that is modular that is able to
expand beyond that. So that's for us
again there are many different
challenges that's been for us the most
effective way of being able to navigate
some of those um some of those
scalability challenges. I'd say just
from a behavioral perspective, it's it's
a big shift in ways of working and
there's definitely a a an enablement or
change management aspect of this that
maybe doesn't present itself in the
early stages when you're building a PC
or an MVP or even a V1 or a V2 of this
capability, but you do get to a point
where it has started to become so
embedded in the ways of working that
change management is important. Whether
it's our clients needing that, whether
it's us, whether it's us needing that,
whether it's someone else needing that,
it's something I I want to make sure we
don't skip over because it is important
as this scales. As we come to a close,
what's a mindset shift that you think
unlocks the most value when it comes to
AI? That's a good question. I think I
would to pick one. I would say to move
away from kind of chat GPT thinking and
I think chat GPT has been both a boon
and a curse for AI because it's a very
specific interaction in a very specific
format that is somewhat linked to a
behavior that we're very much trained
trained into already which is kind of
your Google behavior. Hey, I want to
know something. I'm going to ask a
question. And it's been so helpful for
so many things in a day-to-day. I use it
a lot. I plan all my vacations around uh
with with chat GBT. I use it for
recipes. I I use it a lot from an
enterprise perspective. What it's done
is it has a little bit I think train
some people to think of enterprise AI as
kind of like that like a chatbot like a
a way to um answer questions and and
it's a little bit ingrained that kind of
that kind of interaction when I think
what is more helpful is to think of AI
as a way to improve your decision-
making. We make so many decisions in any
role, in any function, at any seniority
level every single day. And for us, what
we're looking for is of all those
decision nodes, how can we use AI to
make as many of them more effective as
possible? How can we get closer to the
right decision in in as many cases as we
can? And that for us is is what is
really interesting that augmented
decision-m is a really that's the kind
of compounding unlock of AI, at least at
the enterprise level. So I think one of
the behavior shifts is is just getting
more comfortable with that and and part
of that is just adoption and and
education and and the growth of the
industry. For those listening and
wondering whether BOI could be a fit for
their business, who's the right partner
to you? Whether it's a vertical, whether
it's an office or a business unit,
whether it's a size, who's a good fit
for BOI? Yeah. So we work primarily in
the consumer goods, the food and bev
financial services, healthcare and the
industrial space. I will say that mostly
we work in mid-market and large
enterprises. So those are the size
ranges that we are most effective for.
Generally companies in that realm that
are either more advanced with AI and are
thinking about how do we turn this into
compounding AI system? How do we take
all these different pilots that we have
and and turn this into something
scalable and systemized is is a really
great conversation for us to have, but
also people that just have not done
anything with AI. There's not too many
out there now at the company level, but
folks that are also much earlier in
their adoption journey, we we do a lot
of work with as well. Amazing. Amir,
thank you for coming on to just curious
and sharing your perspectives on AI and
how enterprises can hopefully use it to
create uh a compounding machine and more
value in the future. Thanks, dude. I
appreciate it. Thank

cleanText:
Today on Just Curious, we're joined by Amir Ouki, a sharp, commercially minded AI strategist who helps some of the world's biggest companies reimagine how they innovate. As managing director of Applied AI at BOI, Amir leads teams building AI native capabilities for clients across consumer goods, healthcare, financial services, and more. He's worked with cutting edge companies like Anthropic, Apple, Palantir, and Airbnb. And he's known for making bold, complex systems actually work at scale. In this conversation, you'll learn how companies are compressing product development from months to days using agentic systems and synthetic consumers. Why off-the-shelf AI tools often fall short and how Amir builds secure IPOed systems instead, and how to avoid AI theater by anchoring everything in commercial logic and business outcomes.

Amir, welcome to Just Curious.

Hey Stu, happy to be here.

You've worked at the intersection of strategy, design, and technology. Can you tell us a little bit more about your journey and what drew you to focus on AI?

Yeah, for sure. So, I originally started more on the strategy side of things, more traditional strategy. So working through business strategy, commercial strategy and brand strategy and eventually found myself at the software intersection and working in building software at a really great studio called Fictive Kin and started to really immerse in what strategic technology is. So building systems that are scalable, that are modular, but ultimately that are really solving business challenges, which lends itself obviously very, very clearly to AI, which I consider to be a highly strategic technology. It's a technology that we can leverage, that we can design, that we can manipulate into solving challenges that were just really, really hard before. So my journey has been somewhat of an organic one through strategy, software, and then eventually merging the two into strategic technology.

Tell us a little bit more about BOI and what you do and who you did it for.

Yeah, so BOI, we have two main areas of focus, which are AI strategy, so broadly helping companies identify when, where, and how to use AI in their organizations, and then the second focus is technology. So thinking about how to build real-world AI solutions that are solving real-world challenges, and a lot of those different solutions, those different capabilities are usually in the space of augmented decision-making, simulation, genic workflows, as you said earlier, and also starting to do a lot more work now in the field of agentic commerce. So BOI, we are a global company, and I head up America's region over here in our New York office, and we also have a very big Europe market as well, based out of Belgium.

We're going to walk through how BOI helps clients develop and innovation capabilities and turn signals into products. But I'd love to share a little bit more from your learnings as a setup, and maybe we could start with what to do with AI.

Okay. So, a lot of leaders are being told, "Do something with AI," but they don't know where to start. When you're working with a team, how do you help them define a real business use case and a place to start?

Mhm. It's really, really important. So, whenever we are really doing anything in AI, we always start from the challenge first and not AI. So, that ability, that kind of business strategy that I mentioned earlier is really important. You have to know what your challenges are. You have to be able to articulate them. You have to also be able to kind of deconstruct them into sub-challenges. And then once you've got a really good sense of what you are trying to solve for, that's the right time to say, "Okay, what kind of AI technologies will help us solve this?" I think we see a lot of people start with the latter, and they'll see AI around or see a specific use case of AI or maybe a specific vendor and then try and reverse engineer that back into their system. But that's really hard to do. It's always easier, and you're in a better position as a company to say, "What are our challenges? What do we need to solve?" and then say, "Okay, how do we need to go out and solve them?" So we focus primarily on identification, what are those challenges, and then evaluating them, saying what, figuring out essentially what needs to be solved, how it needs to be solved, how we got there, what the right AI technologies could be, and then we think about prioritization, right? So of all these different challenges that we have and all the different use cases that could emerge from them with AI, how do we prioritize these into impact? How do we think about feasibility? How do we think about what a scalable system starts to look like, and then let that guide what an initial foray could be.

You said in our earlier conversation that growth is back on everyone's mind, but headcount isn't the preferred lever it once was. What kind of problems does AI let companies solve now that they couldn't solve before?

Yeah, I think what we see is, is to that point, it's an interesting and somewhat tricky market that we're in at the moment when it comes to the economy, and that's very much on the mind of every client that we work with, and it has been for a little while. So, a lot of them are approaching AI from the lens of, "We may not have the budget and the resources to expand our headcount as aggressively as we could previously." So where is there a role for AI in still allowing us to scale the really great talent that we have, but be able to think about how we can augment that? So I think the example that, um, this kind of position you're referencing is what we call the previously impossible, right? So what could we, what can we do with AI today that we previously couldn't do? And I think there's different ways to tackle that. One of the big ones is just being able to do a lot more with a huge amount of data is the first one that people usually think of. It was very, very difficult before to, let's say, generate insights or generate signals or assess previous data and figure out patterns from previous data. It was very hard to do that manually, and it's still not extremely easy, but it's much easier than it was before to be able to leverage the data sets that you have, whether structured or unstructured, that, um, that just haven't been leveraged before. So the first thing that comes to mind is just the scale of what you can do with AI that you couldn't before by being resource constrained.

I don't want to provide examples that people try and back solve from, but you've worked closely with innovation and transformation and supply chain leaders. Where do you see the biggest opportunities and appetite for AI today?

Yeah, I think that across any function, and we work with different functions and different groups. I think the through line probably is the growth through line. Certainly in the US markets, I think there's three different outcomes usually that people are working towards with AI. And the first one is new revenue. How can we use it to generate new revenue, find new segments, find new audiences, launch new products? The second is revenue optimization. So, how can we use AI to get more out of the products that we already have in market or the services that we have in market? How do we think about our consumers? How do we think about clustering those consumers? How do we think about marketing? And then the third one, which is usually where people's mind begins, is efficiency and productivity, right? How do we use AI to automate? How do we use AI to do what we're already doing, but do it in a more efficient way? And I think that even though that third bucket is where people start, usually it's the other two that is driving meaningful investment in building with AI. It's saying, "Okay, well, actually, if we invest $1 and we can get $2 out of this new capability in terms of new revenue, that's really, really appealing across all functions." And the same for revenue optimization as well. If there's a way that we're able to maximize the growth potential of our existing portfolio of products, it's a really good return compared to just focusing on automation or efficiency or productivity. So while we do work between those different functions that you mentioned, I think that through line is just a drive at the moment for growth and just resiliency in the current market.

And when it comes to that growth, you mentioned revenue optimization, you mentioned new products, segmenting customers in different ways, without going into too much detail, where are kind of the easiest wins there when it comes to applying AI to drive growth? And I asked because one, as you noted, uh, it can create more value than just becoming more efficient. Two, it just runs counter to most of the conversations around AI, which are, "Let's, um, become more efficient," which is code for doing more with the same people or the same with fewer. So yeah, curious for your kind of like high-level thoughts about when it comes to revenue growth, where are kind of the, uh, most interesting opportunities?

Yeah, I mean, as always, it depends on the company, the industry that you're in. And I think just in general with AI, the phrase "quick win" or "easy win" is always one I try to avoid, 'cause I think there's not too many quick wins when it comes to enterprise AI, our personal lives, and AI in the day-to-day that we use. I think there's so many, but when we think about enterprise AI, there's usually a minimum threshold of kind of engagement needed to get some of that return back. But I think where we tend to see people starting are within the existing portfolio of products and services that they may have, depending on what kind of company you are. So thinking about how do you win business at the moment? How can you win more of that business? What are the friction points in your sales cycle, and how can you use AI to minimize some of those friction points? So an example that I would give is that we do quite a bit of work in the industrials sector, and there's a really interesting specific use case around quoting that we see with a lot of manufacturing companies that we work with, where they just have really slow quoting times or really slow turnaround times when they're working with different OEMs and different clients. It's one that AI does lend itself pretty well to. It's a common thread. It's not the most complicated problem to solve, but it does involve a level of customization, given that every company's quoting process is different. If I were to just call out an example of something that comes to mind, that is a relatively, for want of a better phrase, quick hit when it comes to revenue driving. Something like that is, I think, a good example. Just something as simple as quoting and turnaround times and how different companies are able to get proposals out the door. We've heard of proposals from manufacturing companies sometimes taking six weeks to reach the client, which by that point, obviously, is somewhat compromising the revenue potential.

Yeah. Interesting. Many teams start with off-the-shelf tools, and certainly when it comes to enterprise adoption, whether it's enterprise licenses of your kind of model of choice, that was the first step. Why do they often fall short, and how do you help these teams build custom solutions that actually scale?

Yeah, the buy versus build question is a really, it's a really tricky one. There is no right or wrong is the first thing that we always say. Build is not always right. Buy is not always right. We ourselves are not affiliated with any vendors. So we, I think, have a strong neutral position, and we're constantly assessing different tools and different vendors and different SAS solutions out there. I think where we've seen SAS starts to break, certainly at the enterprise level, is twofold. One is the data, the data question. We work with a lot of companies that just are not in a position to let their data leave their own environment, let alone go off into a SAS tool. This is the case with every Fortune 500 company that we work with. There's just no chance that they're using a, uh, an external SAS tool and putting their data into it. So what they're ultimately able to do if they do use a vendor is to just be able to use it as an outsider. They're not able to actually leverage that data. So they don't get so much value out of it. So one is the data security question, and the second is the customization. And whenever we're building any kind of AI capability, it really is designed with that team in mind. So we're thinking about what is the specific commercial logic that is relevant to that team. We're also thinking about how do they work right now? What is their existing process? What makes them really strong? What are the blockers individually that they have, and how can we unblock those obstacles in whatever we're building for them? So that level of, I guess, customization is probably the word you just can't get with different SAS tools. So those are the two big blockers that I would say that prevent, at least the clients that we work with, from being able to meaningfully engage with. But I think for smaller companies, there's a really interesting opportunity there, and it just doesn't make sense for a lot of them to be building that kind of platform from the ground up.

Yeah. Do you think AI is different than prior technology shifts with respect to its enablement of a startup ecosystem? I asked because there are thousands of AI startups, but to your point, for many companies, an off-the-shelf startup solution is not going to work, whether it's, you know, data or something else. Do you think AI is just different and that these startups are going to have a harder time? You've heard about, as an example, agentic startups transitioning, let's call it, to more of a service provider model. Um, curious for your thoughts on that.

Yeah, it's an interesting one. So just kind of a caveat, we don't do too much work as BOI in the startup space itself, but I'll say just kind of as an observer, I think that it is going to be a tricky market for a lot of the AI startups that have emerged in the last year or two. I do think that it'll end up likely being a winner-takes-all situation as with software all the time. So I think a lot of the startups are going to struggle. I think likely one of their biggest competitors is, it's not going to be each other, it's going to be internal teams. I think that where they will struggle is just companies building some version of these capabilities themselves. So as we kind of democratize access to building tools both for people that don't have technical teams, but companies that do have technical teams already, it just is a lot easier for them to stand up at least an MVP version of what a lot of the SAS companies out there are doing. That's certainly not all of them, and this is definitely just a hunch, and I think it's so important to have a healthy ecosystem, but I do think it's going to be choppy waters potentially.

Let's talk about agents for a minute. What do you mean when you talk about agent


IC reasoning systems and how do they fit into and help transform enterprise workflows?

Yeah, it's a really good question.
So, we think of the um the whole agent sphere as being much more of a spectrum.
And there was definitely a moment in time, I would say around a year ago, maybe even 6 months ago, where agents were very much on everyone's mind.
And I think that there was almost kind of a land grab for who could define what an agent was.
And you just heard all these different definitions of what an agent really is.
It needs to be autonomous.
It needs to be self-hosted.
You know, it was kind of a marketing frenzy around agents.
But the way that we think about it is less the individual entity itself.
So when I think of when people tend to reference an agent, they're usually thinking of some kind of defined entity that is acting in some kind of defined environment and it could be something like a chatbot for customer service or a research assistant for example.
But I think for us when we're thinking about the value of an agentic system, we think a bit more from the reasoning standpoint.
So almost a spectrum of autonomy where you can have agents that are very much running on predefined paths and you can have agents that are running on paths that are less defined.
I don't think we're anywhere near the point of autonomous agents at the moment and I'm not sure what the future for that would look like.
But we think of agentic reasoning as basically what is that process?
What's that capability by which multiple agents or a system of agents can make decisions, can deconstruct problems, can evaluate outcomes and coordinate actions.
So that for us is the reasoning um the reasoning process and then that gets applied basically to any challenge that we're trying to solve.
We could be using that kind of setup to figure out what a new signal can be in this giant trove of social listening data.
It could be that we are using this kind of agentic setup for scenario modeling or to do more complex simulation.
So really it's it's it's fairly agnostic in where it lives.
But that's how we think of it versus just your your agent that you may see from maybe a big tech company or or a lot of the the marketing that you see out there at the moment.

Yeah.
Um I want to show viewers and listeners more of how you work.
We talked earlier about a example of working with a consumer goods company to help them build kind of end-to-end innovation capabilities going from signal to product.
Can you walk us through that process?
Um where where do you start?

Yeah.
So I think that's a a good uh a good use case example maybe to show a our flow of what a typical project works with although none of them are are particularly typical but we have worked with a lot of companies especially in um in consumer goods where the end-to-end new product development capability is a huge part of the business and it's also a very complex part of the business.
So we've been actually building AI capabilities that will run that entire process really end to end with the existing new product development team and that could be an innovation team, it could be an R&D team.
Often times it's it's sometimes sales and marketing teams that are running the go to markets portion of this process.
It's generally a collaborative kind of inter team capability but it can start with innovation or transformation usually but we are essentially using AI to start with a signal and different sets of signals.
So we'll take internal data, we'll take external data out there in the world, we'll take third party data, meaning data that one of these companies is is already purchasing or has purchased or has a license agreement from one of their vendors.
We take all of that and then we'll use essentially AI systems to generate opportunity spaces from those.
Well, generate insights from those, then turn those insights into opportunity spaces and then start to really ideulate and concept and think about what could new products look like, what could new services look like, what could new business models look like, for example.
And then take those and then rigorously test them again through simulation, through really rigorous synthetic testing.
And we'll use that agentic reasoning approach that I mentioned earlier to figure out, okay, does this meet desirability requirements?
Does this meet feasibility requirements?
Does this meet viability requirements?
And doing that end to end, you can get from a set of just raw data that's out there in the world to a really refined final concept.
It could be for a new product.
It could be an adjustment on an existing product.
So, it doesn't necessarily have to be just new product development or innovation.
It can be your existing portfolio.
But you can get from that signal to launch really, really fast.
And it's just been very empowering, I think, for a lot of the teams that we've been working with to be able to take a process that typically would have taken them a lot of manual work over 6 8 months and be able to get to really validated new product development much much faster.
And then what we see for those roles is that they're actually able to spend a lot more time now prototyping it and making it real and testing it with real people instead of spending so much time on the funnel process where a lot of the ideas ultimately are and invested in ideas that are not not ready to go to market.
It's been a a really fun it's been a really fun capability.
We've done it quite a bit for companies actually in many different sectors.
For people who have not done that with you before, you mentioned you're able to compress the sort of the calendar from 6 to 8 months to something much shorter.
Understanding everything is different for each individual situation and client like approximately how much compression can one expect from using a AI powered process like this.

Mhm.
Depending on what the process looks like, it's very different for different folks.
So we design it, we build it in a different way for each of the teams we work with.
We have some teams that really will lean into functionality like forecasting or opportunity sizing.
We have other teams that are more interested in functionality like turning those concepts into factory ready production specs.
So just for context, it can it can live and express in different ways, but I'd say end to end it comes down to just a couple of days, which is a pretty substantial change.

Yeah.
You mentioned synthetic consumers and customers.
What does that mean?

So essentially what we're doing is we are replicating the behaviors, the intrinsic motivations especially of traditional consumers.
So we are trying to get them as close as possible to a set of sometimes personas, sometimes archetypes that often times companies may have to start with.
They may have really rigorous persona uh persona data.
They may have incomplete persona data which we're enriching with AI.
But essentially what we're trying to do is we're mirroring real human behaviors as closely as we can.
So it's the behaviors and it's the intrinsic motivators as well that are behind those behaviors.

What do you say to people who push back and say, "But these aren't real."

I think that's very correct.
It it absolutely is not real.
And one of the first things that we always say is that this the outcome of this is to get as close as we can to winning ready services and concepts, ideas that will perform really well in marketing, get you as close as possible.
There's always a human in the loop and there will always be a human making the decisions throughout this process and saying okay this is what we want to explore further this is what we might put into physical prototyping and a lot of the time our clients will say okay great we've got three winning concepts here let's put this in the hands of real consumers which which is important we actually have one client that hasn't done that and quite literally ships these concepts straight to factories and tests them in market from the get- go it's going straight to a factory It's then getting deployed straight to three or four stores.
It's a retail client and they'll get a sense in those stores of how the product is performing with real actual purchase data.
Have people bought this or not?
If they have, then this is a good signal for us to expand this to to other stores.
But that's that's an exception.
For everyone else, it does end up in the hands of real consumers.
And for now, I would advise that that that continues.
So, the goal is not to replace consumers entirely.
The goal is how can we get to you know winning.
Uh any other challenges whether technical or cultural or strategic that you face when deploying these kind of systems?

You know there are many many different challenges that are um involved in just AI in general.
Uh the obvious one is thinking about data scalability.
Uh we always always always approach building anything from an MVP an MVP approach your kind of traditional start small focus on just proving out the key hypothesis and a lot of our clients are multibrand clients so they uh they'll have a lot of household names we'll say let's pick one and let's test out uh let's test out this capability on just this one brand or this one category within the business but we always say start with a PC prove out the value first and then build it in a way that is scalable that is modular that is able to expand beyond that.
So that's for us again there are many different challenges that's been for us the most effective way of being able to navigate some of those um some of those scalability challenges.
I'd say just from a behavioral perspective, it's it's a big shift in ways of working and there's definitely a a an enablement or change management aspect of this that maybe doesn't present itself in the early stages when you're building a PC or an MVP or even a V1 or a V2 of this capability, but you do get to a point where it has started to become so embedded in the ways of working that change management is important.
Whether it's our clients needing that, whether it's us, whether it's us needing that, whether it's someone else needing that, it's something I I want to make sure we don't skip over because it is important as this scales.
As we come to a close, what's a mindset shift that you think unlocks the most value when it comes to AI?

That's a good question.
I think I would to pick one.
I would say to move away from kind of chat GPT thinking and I think chat GPT has been both a boon and a curse for AI because it's a very specific interaction in a very specific format that is somewhat linked to a behavior that we're very much trained trained into already which is kind of your Google behavior.
Hey, I want to know something.
I'm going to ask a question.
And it's been so helpful for so many things in a day-to-day.
I use it a lot.
I plan all my vacations around uh with with chat GBT.
I use it for recipes.
I I use it a lot from an enterprise perspective.
What it's done is it has a little bit I think train some people to think of enterprise AI as kind of like that like a chatbot like a a way to um answer questions and and it's a little bit ingrained that kind of that kind of interaction when I think what is more helpful is to think of AI as a way to improve your decision- making.
We make so many decisions in any role, in any function, at any seniority level every single day.
And for us, what we're looking for is of all those decision nodes, how can we use AI to make as many of them more effective as possible?
How can we get closer to the right decision in in as many cases as we can?
And that for us is is what is really interesting that augmented decision-m is a really that's the kind of compounding unlock of AI, at least at the enterprise level.
So I think one of the behavior shifts is is just getting more comfortable with that and and part of that is just adoption and and education and and the growth of the industry.
For those listening and wondering whether BOI could be a fit for their business, who's the right partner to you?
Whether it's a vertical, whether it's an office or a business unit, whether it's a size, who's a good fit for BOI?

Yeah.
So we work primarily in the consumer goods, the food and bev, financial services, healthcare and the industrial space.
I will say that mostly we work in mid-market and large enterprises.
So those are the size ranges that we are most effective for.
Generally companies in that realm that are either more advanced with AI and are thinking about how do we turn this into compounding AI system?
How do we take all these different pilots that we have and and turn this into something scalable and systemized is is a really great conversation for us to have, but also people that just have not done anything with AI.
There's not too many out there now at the company level, but folks that are also much earlier in their adoption journey, we we do a lot of work with as well.

Amazing.
Amir, thank you for coming on to Just Curious Newsletter and sharing your perspectives on AI and how enterprises can hopefully use it to create uh a compounding machine and more value in the future.

Thanks, dude.
I appreciate it.
